title: Any good way to learn Arabic pronunciation? - Quora

response.answer_text: Use your tongue and first feel the portion of mouth behind the upper teeth. You can feel a hard fart portion of mouth. This portion is called alveolar ridge. Then move your tongue behind the alveolar ridge you can feel the dome shaped part of mouth. This dome shaped part is called palate. There is also another part called velar ridge behind palate that cannot be touched by the tip of the tongue. This can be touched only by back of tongue. When we pronounce letter k or g our tongue touches velar ridge. Alveolar ridge is used in pronunciation of n, t and d. Fricatives are consonants with characteristics that when they are produced air escapes through a small passage and makes a hissing sound. There is no contact between tongue and mouth . There is a small gap between tongue and mouth. Fricatives are letter s , z , sh, ch. Articulation happens when the tongue either touches / is in contact with alveolar, palatal and velar ridge. Each pair of the following have same place of articulation but they differ in usage of vocal cords. No Vocal cords / vocal cords T / D P / B S / Z K / G Ch / Sh Those consonants which use vocal cords are called voiced consonants. Velarised consonants are consonants in which the mid/back of tongue is near the velar ridge . Exampl ب Or B When two lips come in contact and we suddenly open our mouth we pronounce the letter b. We use vocal cords. Th of the word "the" For Native speaker the consonant is a fricative pronounced when the tongue is about to touch the upper teeth but doesn't touch the teeth. T It is pronounced when our tongue touches the alvelor ridge. Only the tip of the tongue touches the alveolar ridge. ت This consonant is pronounced when the tip of tongue touches the back gums of upper teeth. The alvelor ridge is completely in contact with portion of tongue behind tip of tongue whereas for t only the tip of tongue is in contact with alveolar ridge and the tip is little behind the articulation of t. ط The articulation is similar to ت but the mid/back tongue is near to touch the velar ridge where as the tongue is not near velar ridge as ت. It sounds like the of the for Asians or non native speakers. د This consonant has same articulation of ت but vocal cords are used in this. It sounds like the of the for Asians or non native speakers. ز This consonant is about to touch the alveolar like but doesn't touch the alveolar ridge. It sounds like Z. ض This consonant has same articulation like but the mid/back of tonue is near the velar ridge but doesn't contact velar ridge. The side of tongue touches the side teeth . It sounds like z. ظ This consonant has same articulation like but the mid/back of tonue is near the velar ridge but doesn't contact velar ridge. The side of tongue does not touch the side teeth like . Vocal cords are used. It sounds like z . س This letter is produced like ت but the difference is that the tongue doesn't touch the alveolar ridge and it gives way for air to pass. It sounds like s . ص This letter has articulation as س but the mid/back of tonue is near the velar ridge but doesn't contact velar ridge. Try to pronounce ksa you will find difficulty while pronouncing this . Now avoid making k sound but the tongue should be near velar ridge. It sounds like s . ث This pronounced like th of thin pronounced by native speakers. The tip of tongue is behind the front upper teeth , it is not near the alveolar ridge . Tongue doesn't contact teeth. It lets air to pass through gap. It sounds like a for non native speakers. ذ This pronounced like th of thin pronounced by native speakers. The tip of tongue is behind the front upper teeth , it is not near the alveolar ridge . Tongue doesn't contact teeth. It lets air to pass through gap. For a native speaker it sounds like th of word the and for non native speaker it sounds like z . ش This articulation is alveolar palatal. The half of front part of tongue is near the alveolar ridge similar to s and half of the front part of tongue is near the palatal region this half part doesn't contact the palate. The front part of tongue is not in contact with mouth roof. It is like sh in ship. ج This articulation is alveolar palatal. The half of front part of tongue is in contact with the alveolar ridge similar to t and half of the front part of tongue is near the palatal region this half part doesn't contact the palate. It is like j in jug. ل The articulation is same as ت but the tongue remains in contact with alveolar ridge . Air passes through the sides of the standing tongue. ك The mid/back of tongue touches the velar ridge. The air is trapped and released. ق The back of tongue is in contact with throat much deeper than velar ridge. It is not like k. ح The back of tongue is near with throat much deeper than velar ridge but doesn't touch the throat. It is much like but it is a fricative. خ The back of tongue is near with throat much deeper than velar ridge but doesn't touch the throat .Also the mid/back of tongue is near the velar ridge but doesn't contact it. ع The back of tongue is near throat much deeper than velar ridge but doesn't touch the throat . There is no h sound in this . Vocal cords are used in this just as we pronounce vowels. غ The back of tongue is near throat much deeper than velar ridge but doesn't touch the throat . The mid/back tongue is near velar ridge. It is much like خ. The difference between them is using vocal cordsThere is no h sound in this . Vocal cords are used in this just as we pronounce vowels ف The upper teeth come in slight with lower lip . Air is passed . Air is passed through the small gap between upper teeth and lower lip . ى The mid of tongue is near the palate . There is no contact. Vocal cords are used. و The lips are slightly rounded. Less Air passes through the slightly rounded lips . Vocals cord are used. ة Air is passed through vocal cords. There is no relation of tongue and mouth in this consonant. Pronounced like vowel in cup. ن The consonant has same articulation as ت but no air passes out of mouth . Slight air passes through nose . Nose is very important in this consonant pronunciation. ء Air is suddenly stopped by the closure of vocal cords. Mostly heard in native speakers pronunciation of t in hat. They don't make t sound there but a glottal stop. ر For native speakers the tongue goes near the alveolar ridge but doesn't contact with it. Lips are rounded . Vocal cords are used. For Asians or non native speakers it is a flap. The tongue comes and contacts the alveolar ridge and then releases the air suddenly. Just try to pronounce rr made by tractors. Arabic ر is similar to Asians R. Rounding lips are not used in pronunciation of Arabic letters. Rounding of lips is done for sh, ch, j and r of English but not done in any Arabic alphabets. Vowels. “u" Is much like the vowel in took . “uu"Is much like long vowel in spoon. “a” much like the vowel in cup. “aa”Is much like long vowel in far. “I"Is much like vowel in spin. “Ii"Is much like long vowel in teen. I prepared this answer for a similar question which was deleted just now while I was writing. I'm a native English speaker, so obviously you are better off learning from a native Arabic speaker. But maybe the tricks I learned while struggling to learn unfamiliar Arabic sounds 50 years ago will help someone else. The h sound in Ahmad is the letter hha. It is an unvoiced pharyngeal stop pronounced at the base of the throat. More about it later. The corresponding voiced pharyngeal stop is the letter `ayin. When I studied Arabic 50 years ago, I went around for weeks trying unsuccessfully to say it. One day, in the Boston Zoo, I heard a camel make a sound very much like that in its throat. I imitated it, and I think it's a fair approximation of an `ayin. I don't intend any insult. Hebrew still has that sound among some speakers, and maybe guttural sounds like that are natural in a desert climate. Once I figured out `ayin, I figured out its unvoiced form hha (hhet in Hebrew), as in Ahmad about which you asked. The letter qaf, as pronounced in readings of the Qur'an and in Modern Standard Arabic, but not in many spoken Arabic dialects, is a k in the back of your throat, like the cawing of a crow. The letter ghayin is somewhat like a French r. The 4 emphatic letters sahd, dahd, tah, thah are pronounced by pushing the middle of your tongue against the roof of your mouth and pulling it away suddenly while pronouncing s, d, t, or th as in that. I think dahd is easiest to learn first. These letters color adjacent vowels darker. The kh sound is rough, like Scottish ch in loch. But you should listen to recordings of native Arabic speakers making these sounds. Look in Google. And maybe you need a tutor to listen to you.

To learn pronunciation you have first to learn makharij Alhoroof (the emission points of the letters). It tells you exactly where should you place your tougue and lips. Just search it and you will find videos and photos on this.   ​​The second thing is try to read a "mushakkal" book, you will notice that the writing and pronunciation are matching. There are some exception like (الإله، عمرو، مائة ) but mostly they match. Later, reading a non-mushakkal book is not a big deal. The difficulty in Arabic is not in the pronunciation (except makharij Alhoroof in the beginning which needs exercise) but in (النحو والصرف والبلاغة).

A2AAs a non-native to Hebrew, that suffers from the same affliction, I'd like to have a magic solution for you (and for me), but, unfortunately, there is not any. You follow the rules when it comes to the verbs, open the dictionary (paper or online) for each new word and when in doubt - use "a" like in "much".

I wonder if the difficulty you're having is with what the poster below describes - the use of small vowel signs above and below the consonant letters. However, you say that there are exceptions in the letter combination and spelling: do you mean that it's the fact that the consonant letters change their form depending on the surrounding letters? If so that may not be a problem with pronunciation as such, but with the writing system. There's another factor, which is that the exact pronunciation of a sound, as in other languages generally, does vary according to the surrounding sounds. If the vowel (not the letter) /a/ is preceded by the consonant /S/ (sa:d) the 'a' is not pronounced as it is when it's preceded by /s/ (si:n).
